Britain’s <color=#009300>highly-disciplined</color> infantry is famed for its accuracy, delivering volleys with a steadiness few can match. Supported by <color=#009300>good auxiliaries</color> from Hanover and Hesse, their armies combine English professionalism with German reliability. Yet the redcoats are <color=#CB2225>few in number</color>, fielding smaller battalions, and require <color=#CB2225>high standards</color> of training, making promotions to veteran units time-consuming.

Historical Rivals: France (fought France, Austria, Russia during the Seven Years' War)
Fields small, accurate armies with poor melee abilities. Hessian and Hanoverian auxiliaries provide full-sized formations and reliable hand-to-hand strength.

France fields <color=#009300>massive armies</color> supported by renowned <color=#009300>heavy cavalry</color>, excelling in sweeping, overwhelming assaults. Yet these great hosts are plagued by <color=#CB2225>fragile morale</color>, and the strain of supplying so many men is worsened by <color=#CB2225>poor logistics</color>, as corruption and lavish spending drain resources. When their spirit holds, however, French armies can deliver devastating blows on the battlefield.

Historical Rivals: Britain and Austria (fought Britain and Prussia during the Seven Years' War)
Raises massive armies with strong melee but low morale. Swiss auxiliaries steady the line, the Irish strike hard, and German units reload quickly.

Austria’s <color=#009300>flexible</color> multinational army is anchored by <color=#009300>great artillery</color>, giving it strength in prolonged battles. But the same diversity that makes the army adaptable also leaves its recruits difficult to integrate, with fresh levies from many lands often <color=#CB2225>slow to train</color>. Combined with <color=#CB2225>poor reload</color> times on the line, Austria relies on adaptability and the ferocity of its Hungarian troops to balance these flaws.

Historical Rivals: Prussia and France (fought Prussia and Britain during the Seven Years' War)
Maintains balanced and diverse forces. Regulars are average, Hungarians excel in shock, Grenzers dominate at ranged fire, and Hussars threaten flanks.

The Russian army fields <color=#009300>cheap recruits</color> and is held together with <color=#009300>excellent morale</color>, allowing it to endure long and punishing campaigns. But recruitment is <color=#CB2225>disorganized</color>, as Russia struggles with logistics far from the motherland, and their <color=#CB2225>slow movements</color> leave them vulnerable to quicker opponents. Even so, when brought to battle, the Russians prove a determined and unyielding foe.

Historical Rivals: France and Prussia (fought Prussia and Britain during the Seven Years' War)
Deploys vast, resilient armies with high morale. Though slow and inaccurate, they can sustain much fire without buckling, while Cossacks harass relentlessly.

Prussia’s <color=#009300>fast infantry</color> is drilled to march and reload with unmatched efficiency, enabling daring maneuvers. Their <color=#009300>heavy infantry</color> forms the backbone of this disciplined army, holding firm in brutal contests. But Prussia’s reliance on its infantry comes at a cost: the <color=#CB2225>artillery corps</color> is neglected by commanders, and maintaining such elite forces means fielding <color=#CB2225>expensive units</color> that are difficult to replace.

Historical Rivals: Austria, Russia (fought France, Austria, Russia during the Seven Years' War)
Fields average-sized but elite armies. Known for rapid reloads and swift maneuver, with heavy infantry that instill fear on the battlefield.
Explore different regions across Europe and face harsher conditions and unique encounters across three acts.
Unlock different armies and compositions between multiple nations, each with their own playstyle.
Gain specialized regiments, items and doctrines that control the battlefield and develop powerful officer skills to shape your campaign.
Item, Ammunition A tin canister packed with musket balls, turning field guns into oversized shotguns. Devastating at close range against dense infantry lines.
Item, Ammunition A desperate but brutal solution: two canisters rammed in at once. Risky for the crew, ruinous for anything in front of the barrel.
Item, Ammunition Larger iron balls tied in canvas, meant to shred cavalry or clustered men. Preferred at medium range for its wider spread and terrorizing effect.
Item, Ammunition A modified musket load filled with small lead pellets, trading accuracy for a lethal spray. Favored in ambushes or by skirmishers.
Item, Ammunition A .65 caliber ball with several buckshot pellets. Balanced lethality, often used by troops expecting close, chaotic fighting.
Item, Ammunition Standard musket balls cut into shards. Crude but effective, causing grisly wounds and often used when ammunition was short.
Item, Grenades A pouch of thin glass globes filled with powder and shards. Light and throwable at longer ranges, but fragile and inconsistent in detonation.
Item, Grenades A greater quantity of the same light, long-range glass grenades. Preferred by troops needing reach over reliability.
Item, Grenades Compact iron shells designed to fragment on detonation. Heavier, shorter-ranged, but more dependable than glass.
Item, Grenades An expanded supply of the same iron grenades. Suited for prolonged engagements or well-equipped assault parties.
Item, Ramrods A full set of precision-forged tools for swabbing, loading, and venting. Keeps artillery crews working faster under pressure.
Item, Gun Tools Threaded devices fitted behind the barrel to adjust angle with accuracy. Allows for more consistent long-range fire.
Item, Ramrods Heavier and sturdier than wood, these iron tools make reloading smoother and less prone to breakage in the heat of battle.
Item, Ramrods Uniformly machined rods that glide down the barrel with ease. Favored by disciplined units aiming to fire first and often.
Item, Field Implements Compact spades and pickaxes carried in the kit. Used to dig quick cover or reinforce natural defenses before the shots fly.
Item, Field Implements Rural polearms adopted by irregulars and light infantry. Doubles as a walking stick and a weapon, with the added benefit of hacking out fieldworks.
Item, Field Implements A mark of rank, etched in brass and steel. Not just ceremonial, these double as weapons and inspire troops to follow their bearer.
Item, Gun Tools Tight-fitting barrel plugs that reduce fouling and moisture. Small refinement, noticeable decrease in missfires.
Item, Gun Tools Specially hardened tools to clear vent holes and dislodge powder residue. Speeds up loading for seasoned hands.
Item, Staff Officers An officer trained in field fortifications and battlefield preparation. His presence ensures every rise and hedge is made into a redoubt.
Item, Staff Officers Keeps strict records and stricter discipline. Ammunition is distributed sparingly but effectively under his oversight.
Item, Staff Officers Knows every man by name and every crate by weight. Under his watch, the regiment drills harder and learns faster.
Item, Staff Officers A veteran of the frontier or the hunt, brought in to refine the regiment’s aim. Encourages deadly precision at the cost of speed.
Item, Staff Officers Brings not just tools, but hard-earned experience in stitching flesh and calming nerves. Fewer men die where he walks.
Item, Staff Officers Delivers fire and comfort in equal measure. His sermons can steel wavering hearts and calm the fear of death.
Item, Musicians The steady rhythm of fife and drum keeps men in line and spirits high. On a chaotic field, the beat can be as vital as a volley.
Item, Musicians Oboes and other courtly instruments lend a different tone. Less rigid, more spirited. Unfamiliar, yet enough to lift feet and morale alike.
Item, Musicians Shrill, defiant, and impossible to ignore. Their music drives men into the fray with fire in their veins.
Item, Ammunition Containers Well-made leather boxes with tighter seals and better stitching. Slows the rate of waste and makes each shot count.
Item, Ammunition Containers Bulkier design with more room for cartridges. Keeps men firing longer, though the added weight wears them down faster.
Item, Ammunition Containers A reinforced artillery chest with better compartmentalization. Reduces spillage and keeps powder and shot dry under fire.
Item, Ammunition Containers Carries more ammunition for prolonged bombardments. The extra load comes at a cost to crew endurance.
Item, Haversacks Light and comfortable, with padded straps and better balance. Boosts stamina and keeps spirits up on the march.
Item, Haversacks Fitted to carry more personal items and rations. Lifts morale, though the added burden slows the step slightly.
Item, Canteens Refitted with metal linings and tight stoppers. Keeps water cooler and cleaner, helping men endure longer days.
Item, Canteens Holds more, and that can make all the difference. Heavier to carry, but the extra water delays exhaustion.
Item, Horseshoes Balanced iron fittings shaped for steady strides. Grants cavalry a more stamina and swifter pace across the field.
Item, Saddles Slim and efficient designs for quick movement. Popular among cavalrymen who favor sustaining high speeds.
Item, Saddles Built for stability and control in hand-to-hand combat. Heavier, offering only a slight speed increase.
Item, Footwear Covers the ankle and lower calf, offering some protection while keeping the stride light. Helps men last longer on the march.
Item, Footwear Tall, tight-fitting legwear that guards against mud, brush, and fatigue. Marching becomes quicker and easier over time.
Item, Footwear Simple but reliable footwear with reinforced soles. Speeds up the pace without sacrificing comfort.
Item, Footwear Polished and tall, designed for the saddle but worn by officers and dragoons alike. Adds a touch of flair and a great deal of speed.
Item, Blankets Worn across the chest, these bedrolls double as padding in close combat. Boosts morale and softens a few blows.
Item, Apparel Thick woolen coats that offer warmth and presence. Raise spirits and cushion the impact of enemy blades.
Item, Apparel Dense layers of cloth and leather stitched for durability. Common among cavalry who expect close quarters.
Item, Apparel Hardened and tested against ball and blade. Offers excellent protection but slows the wearer’s advance.
Item, Religion Small enough to fit in a coat, carried close by many. A source of comfort and conviction when steel and smoke close in.
Item, Religion Worn under the uniform or around the neck. Serves as both protection and a reminder of something beyond the battlefield.
Item, Rations Pouches of dried plants and tinctures passed down through tradition. Not always pleasant, but often effective in the right hands.
Item, Rations Rolled and lit before or after the fight. Calms the nerves and sharpens the eye, though it takes a toll on the lungs.
Item, Rations Bitter and filling, shared in good cheer. Raises morale and gives the men strength in close combat.
Item, Rations Strong enough to make men brave, or foolish. Best used before the order to fire, not after.
Item, Rations Clear and steadying, a quiet strength in the cup. Sharpens the eye and smooths the rhythm of reloading.
Item, Rations Rich and filling, a soldier’s comfort. Bolsters the spirit and lends endurance for the long march.
Item, Rations Strong and bitter, brewed quickly and gulped down before dawn. Quickens the pace and readies the hands for the shot.
Item, Mascots Small in stature, boundless in spirit. Lifts morale and sharpens the eye, as if its bark carried farther than the musket’s ball.
Item, Mascots Massive and steadfast, a living banner of the regiment. Its presence stiffens resolve and lends strength when the lines clash.
Item, Mascots Lumbering and indomitable, half mascot and half myth. Stories tell of him assisting by hauling shot and powder to the guns!
Item, Mascots Headstrong and unshakable, ever butting to the front. Its stubborn cheer stirs men’s spirits and steadies their aim.
Item, Mascots Lean and tireless, fleet as the wind. Keeps the ranks lively and the march unbroken.
Item, Horses White-coated and noble, a striking mount that lifts the regiment’s spirit. Balanced of pace and presence, it steadies the line as much as it carries it forward.
Item, Horses Lean and enduring, raised on the open plain. Runs long and fast, carrying its rider tireless across the field.
Item, Horses Restless and fiery, born for the clash. Quick to wheel and quicker to strike, it drives its rider headlong into the charge.
Item, Horses Well-bred and sure-footed, swift in the charge and steady under fire. Favored by dragoons for its keen stride and steadiness in the shot.
Item, Horses Dark and imposing, bred for strength over speed. Carries its rider with grim power, lending weight to every stroke of the blade.
Item, Treatises The writings of Maurice de Saxe emphasize resolve and discipline in battle. A favored read among French commanders who fight with both pride and cold steel.
Item, Treatises Notes from the king himself, covering tempo, maneuver, and fire discipline. A must-have for any Prussian officer hoping to follow in his footsteps.
Item, Treatises A bold and aggressive doctrine drawn from Sweden’s lion-king. Promotes relentless charges, though patience is in short supply.
Item, Treatises A Dutch manual on fortification and calculated fire. Precision and positioning are everything in this treatise.
Item, Treatises French theories on deep columns and swift assault. Favored by officers eager to get their men moving and into the enemy’s flank.
Item, Treatises Focuses on loose formation musketry, suited to rough terrain and irregular warfare. Spanish officers credit it with shaping modern skirmishing.
Item, Treatises A British guide to drill and unit cohesion. Stresses repetition and clarity in command, accelerating a regiment’s learning curve.
Item, Treatises Outlines how terrain should be used to full effect. French troops under its guidance can make a hedgerow feel like a fortress.
Item, Treatises Blends range tables with firing drills. British gunners equipped with its insights find their pieces hitting harder and reloading faster.
Item, Treatises A text focused on morale, structure, and reform. Still studied in Prussian academies for its insight into keeping an army steady under strain.
Item, Treatises Concerns itself with logistics and ammunition discipline. French units under its influence keep their powder dry and their volleys measured.

Item, Emplacements Sharpened logs driven into the ground to slow cavalry and channel infantry. Quick to place and surprisingly effective when time is short.
Item, Emplacements Movable barriers lined with spikes. Used to block roads, defend flanks, or buy precious minutes before the lines clash.
Item, Emplacements Hastily dug mounds of soil and reinforced embankments. Offer solid cover and a morale boost to those behind them.

General,
The caches here have long been stripped bare. But a detachment of hussars lingers in the area, unwilling to stand idle. They offer to ride out and seize whatever resource we need most, be it coin, powder, rations, or recruits.

The risk is theirs, but it will take time. A few days at least before they return, assuming they do.

Sir,
This cache was laid down in haste before the ground froze, and though it holds a fair share of coin and cartridges, there is precious little food to be found. The land is no longer yielding as it once did.

We may still collect what remains, some powder, some coin, but the rations will be thin.
We're lucky we've found any food.

Your Grace,
A lightly guarded supply post lies before us, but a handful of enemy stragglers stand watch. Within its walls are captives and stores of provisions and powder. If we strike swiftly, we may seize one part of the stock, or free the prisoners, before the guards can muster a defense. Our scouts report their strength is slight, and our men are confident the fight will be ours.

Your Grace,
We encountered a local pastor tending a modest flock of sheep in a meadow untouched by war. The man has little use for coin but would welcome assistance.

In exchange for some coin, he’s offered to shear his flock and provide us with warm clothes and fresh mutton. A quiet mercy in these opening days of war.
We have much coin to spare.

Sir,
At a nearby farmstead long abandoned, our foragers came across a most determined goat, bold enough to enter camp and help itself to a drummer’s rations.

It has since become a source of amusement and is already following the men about like a sentry. We may adopt it as a regimental beast, or leave it be. The troops seem fond of the idea.

A mascot worthy of the Royal Welch!
(has doctrine <color=#00E5E1>{0}</color>)

Your Grace,
During our march, a towering hound emerged from the woods, by all accounts, a Great Dane. He appears trained and obedient, following commands with surprising discipline.

The men have taken a liking to him, and his presence lends an air of dignity to the column. Shall we keep him on as a regimental mascot?

He's as stubborn as a Frenchman.
(has doctrine <color=#00E5E1>{0}</color>)

Your Grace,
This morning, a greyhound wandered into camp, ribs showing but gait still noble. His collar bears no crest—perhaps a hunting dog left behind in the chaos. He has taken well to the troops and seems to favor the drummer boys in particular.

Shall we take him on?

A fine hound. Prussian discipline will make a soldier of him!
(has doctrine <color=#00E5E1>{0}</color>)

Complexity: <color=#009300>Standard</color>
        In the mid-eighteenth century, Prussia recruits conscripts via a unique canton system. Much like modern reservists, these soldiers are drafted into the army for basic training, but then furloughed to their villages in peacetime. This allows Prussia to maintain a large supply of trained manpower during conflicts. Mobilized Cantonists are not the best trained soldiers in the Prussian army, but they remain loyal infantrymen.

Complexity: <color=#CB2225>Difficult</color>
        During the wars of the 1740s and 1750s, European armies recruit large numbers of Freikorps. These soldiers, sometimes freebooters more like mercenaries, are famous for their specialized skills and uniforms, but frequently desert the army in search of greener pastures. In Prussia and other nations, they are occasionally recruited from prisoners of war.

Complexity: <color=#E2A200>Challenging</color>
        The Prussian army has many regiments hailing back from the days of the Soldier King, Frederick the Great’s father. These troops are highly disciplined and motivated by unit loyalty and esprit de corps. In many of the larger battles of the Seven Years' War, units of Prussian grenadiers spearhead attacks on hazardous positions, even in the face of heavy enemy artillery fire. These are the elite shock troops of the Prussian army.

Complexity: <color=#009300>Standard</color>
        The core power of the Habsburg monarchy comes from its Austrian and Bohemian hereditary lands. In addition to providing much of the wealth of the empire, German- and Czech-speaking infantrymen form the heart of Maria Theresa’s armies. These soldiers are loyal to their Queen, and include men from cities like Prague and Vienna who have rudimentary education in mathematics and ballistics, necessary for the artillery train.

Complexity: <color=#CB2225>Difficult</color>
        Some of the hardiest troops in the Habsburg dominions come from the Militärgrenze, the military border with the Ottoman Empire. Here, Croatian, Hungarian, and other Balkan troops serve, guarding the frontier against possible Ottoman incursions. They are excellent light infantrymen who prize accurate shooting, famous for harassing their enemies with long-range fire.

Complexity: <color=#E2A200>Challenging</color>
        Maria Theresa has an excellent relationship with her Hungarian subjects, famously begging for their assistance during the War of Austrian Succession. These courageous men never forget her humility, providing the Habsburgs with excellent infantry unafraid to charge into close range, and the famed Hungarian hussars who scout and skirmish in front of all Austrian armies.

Complexity: <color=#009300>Standard</color>
        Peter the Great revolutionizes the Russian state in the early eighteenth century, introducing conscription during the Great Northern War. This enables the Russian army to maintain a significant force even in peacetime, as Russian serf soldiers serving for life form new communities centered around their regiments. Their Orthodox faith makes them fearless in the face of death.

Complexity: <color=#009300>Standard</color>
        At the beginning of the Seven Years’ War, Empress Elizabeth Petrovna approves the creation of a new section of the Russian army: the Corps of Observation. These troops fight bravely against the Prussians from entrenched positions at battlefields like Zorndorf and Kunersdorf. They eventually become responsible for protecting the Russian artillery in battle.

Complexity: <color=#CB2225>Difficult</color>
        The Cossack hosts support the Russian military’s efforts in the Seven Years’ War, drawn from their heartlands in the Hetmanate and Zaporizhzhia. These troops develop a fearsome reputation as raiders, devastating the areas they pass through. They provide excellent light cavalrymen for the Russian Empire in the Seven Years’ War.

Complexity: <color=#009300>Standard</color>
        As it prioritizes the colonial war in North America and around the world, William Pitt’s government is hesitant to commit soldiers to the fighting in Germany. When these troops finally arrive in the Holy Roman Empire in 1758, they quickly prove themselves and fight with a courage out of proportion to their small numbers. English infantrymen are famous for their devastating firepower.

Complexity: <color=#CB2225>Difficult</color>
        During the eighteenth century, the Electors of Hanover rule as the Kings of Great Britain in a personal union. The Hanoverian army is in every way the core of the British continental strategy against the French. Ferdinand of Brunswick marches Hanoverian regiments rapidly in his lightning offensives against the French.

Complexity: <color=#E2A200>Challenging</color>
        Hessian and Brunswicker troops are the third section of Ferdinand of Brunswick's western army facing down the French. These soldiers are similar to mercenaries, with their governments paid a subsidy by the British to fight as their allies. As much of the Seven Years' War in western Germany is fought on Hessian territory, these men fearlessly charge through French gunfire to defend their homeland.

Complexity: <color=#009300>Standard</color>
        The French Army of the Lower Rhine is the core instrument of the French monarchy in the Seven Years' War, as the French launch repeated offensives to defeat the Anglo-Prussian alliance. The size and population of France enable large contributions of manpower to this force. Throughout the eighteenth century, French military theorists debate the ideas of Chevalier Folard, who argues that column attacks with cold steel are ideally suited to the character of the French nation.

Complexity: <color=#E2A200>Challenging</color>
        In the War of Austrian Succession, the French begin to experiment with light infantry, such as the Chasseur de Fischer. These troops are excellent at fighting in cover, but also scout for the French forces, giving them advantages in planning operations against their opponents. Their skills continue to be honed in the Seven Years’ War.

Complexity: <color=#CB2225>Difficult</color>
        The Maison du Roi, or King’s Household, is an elite collection of guard troops in the eighteenth century. The French military is famed for its heavy cavalry, who charge home against the enemy on numerous battlefields in the eighteenth century. Their elite status makes them fearless, but the French army begins to fall behind other, more innovative forces.

The tutorial has been deactivated. You can always change this in the game’s options menu.
Welcome to Master of Command! Before you start a campaign, you must select a Nation. Each has its own distinct strengths and weaknesses.

These are the five nations you can select from: Britain, Austria, Prussia, Russia, and France. </line-indent>

Prussia is selected by default, and is a great option for beginners!
Here is your Brigade. A brigade is comprised of an Officer and its Regiments. Depending on the army you've chosen to lead, the brigade will comprise different starting units.

Each army starts with a different configuration of supplies. They include: Provisions, food that is consumed daily. Thalers, money that is used to purchase units and items. Reservists, manpower used to replace losses. Ammunition, ammo used in battles and while drilling. It's also crucial to play into every army's bonus Doctrine. In this case, the "Canton System" grants the Prussian army free reservists every time it visits a settlement. Armies also start with items, these can be equipped to your regiments once the campaign begins.
You may view more details on your items by moving your mouse over them.

Open the settings gear before you begin to set your difficulty. Master of Command is balanced for seasoned strategists. Players new to strategy games are advised to begin on Casual difficulty, few win their first campaign.

Use the unlocks button to open up the game's achievements. Most achievements in Master of Command provide unique unlocks! Ranging from a renowned historical regiment, to a brand new army to command. You can hover over the three icons underneath CHOOSE AN ARMY to see which new armies can be unlocked and which achievement is required to unlock them. Each nation starts with their first army of three already unlocked.

This is the full list of achievements in Master of Command. Achievements drive the progression of the game.
You can use the filters in the top right, selecting flags to toggle off certain nation-specific achievements.

Many nation-specific achievements unlock unique units and entire armies to play as.
If this is your first time playing, select the Captain difficulty preset, and work your way up the ranks in subsequent playthroughs!

Welcome to the mission board. Your aide-de-camp has presented three locations to campaign in. 

Once selected, the other two missions are removed and three new ones are generated later.

Each mission has two unique side-objectives like “Occupy, Support, Raid” etc.

Completing these objectives will reward you with either a unique regiment or a doctrine.

By selecting the map icon in the bottom right corner, you can toggle to the map view in order to see which regions you’ve conquered, or select a region to campaign in. After selecting a mission, press continue to begin your campaign.

You have entered your first campaign region. It is crucial to seize the nearby depot and engage the enemy!

Afterwards, you may move on and look to engage patrols. Even if larger than you, they are typically weaker and provide a great source of income and loot.

Over time, the enemy headquarters will build up and come attack you. You must recruit new units and build a formidable force in order to destroy it.

You may navigate the region by using WASD or by dragging the middle mouse button. Use the right mouse button to move your army, attack enemy armies, or navigate toward towns and encounters found throughout the map.

Terrain matters. Roads allow your army to march faster, whereas forests and rivers slow your army down. 

Mountains cause your army to lose supplies quicker but provide a greater line of sight which can be useful to spot nearby settlements or enemy armies.

Your main and side objectives are listed in the top right corner along with the current date and game speed. 

The campaign is played in real-time. If you’re ever caught in a bad situation, tap the space key to quickly pause!
On the left-hand side of the screen are your army’s stances. Each one has a different effect to aid you on your journey. Hover over a stance to see what it does.

In the top left of your screen, you can see your resources and doctrine, which impact your whole army.</line-indent>

Earn resources by completing encounters, visiting towns, and winning battles. There is a nearby supply cache that will assist you on your campaign.

You have enabled the forced march stance. This consumes more supplies and limits visibility but enables your army to move quicker. 

Remember to select the default stance at the top of the stance bar to stop the forced march.

You have enabled the raiding stance. This drains the <sprite name=gold> thalers and <sprite name=food> provisions from a settlement. Fully raiding a settlement destroys it, making it permanently inaccessible. Your army is stationary during a raid and is vulnerable to enemy patrols. 

Moving cancels the raid stance.

You have enabled the drilling stance. This consumes <sprite name=supply> ammunition but provides passive experience gain for your army and speeds up replenishment time to convalescing units. Your army is stationary in this stance and is vulnerable to enemy attack. Moving cancels the drill stance.

You have enabled the foraging stance. This decreases <sprite name=food> provision consumption and provides further line of sight. Your army moves slower while foraging and will have trouble outrunning enemy patrols. 

Remember to select the default stance at the top of the stance bar to stop foraging.
Welcome to your camp! Here, you manage your army.
This is your starting brigade which comprises a commanding officer and regiments.
You may drag and move your officer and regiments to different locations in the camp.

When you select a regiment, you can see their equipment, stats, and regimental flag. To customize a regiment, click on the flag. You can also rename regiments by clicking on the text directly above the flag.
Here is your inventory. You may equip them to your regiments or sell them in a town to purchase more regiments.
You may also rename and customize your officer by selecting him.
Once ready, you may exit your camp by pressing this button. You can always access the camp.

During battles, your units may suffer casualties and lose ammunition. It is up to you to retrain more soldiers into your regiment as they will not replenish on their own. Replenish your regiment by dragging its green health bar to the right. This consumes reservists. The same can be done with the yellow ammunition bar underneath the health bar.
To transfer a regiment to a new brigade, you may need to purchase a new brigade slot if you can afford it.
In the top right, regiments and officers can be assigned to "reserve." They can replenish here without being brought into combat.
The right side allows you to choose patterns and emblems for you regimental flag.
Some items are mutually exclusive. For example you may not equip multiple ramrods. Also, your regiments may only have one primary and secondary weapon equipped at a time.
For a price, you may open up additional inventory slots only for the selected regiment.

A regiment earned a promotion! When you have gained enough veterancy, you may promote your regiment. Click the badge icon above the secondary-weapon slot: silver means not ready; gold means ready to upgrade. </line-indent>
You may delay upgrades to keep your retain veterancy. Veterancy boosts your units' combat stats.
Earn veterancy through combat or drilling to unlock upgrades. The regiment’s veterancy is shown at the top-center.
Select a regiment in the unit tree to compare stats.
Encounters are campaign events with positive or negative outcomes. Hover options to see details. Some side objectives require completing encounters to earn their rewards.

To battle! Inspect your enemy's regiments and officers on the right panel by hovering over them.

You may choose to begin the battle by selecting the cross swords, or retreat with a penalty.
This is the settlement view. Here you may trade your items, purchase new officers and regiments, or sell your goods.
You may purchase <sprite name=food> provisions, <sprite name=manpower> reservists, and <sprite name=supply> ammunition by using the buttons at the top of the screen.
Settlement modifiers may also be seen here which can affect the goods and prices at this location.
This is the trade screen. Your inventory items and <sprite name=gold> thalers are on the left side.
While the shop owners items and <sprite name=gold> thalers are on the right side.
You may right click or drag items towards the middle to purchase or sell items.
It is winter! You have received the “Winter Quarters” malice under your doctrines. It will remain winter until you destroy the enemy HQ in the region, do not rest on your laurels!
You are facing the enemies headquarters! You cannot retreat. Losing destroys your army and ends the campaign while victory will complete this region.
At the start of every battle, you may move and reposition your units during the deployment phase.
Configure unit stances before the battle begins.
Hold left-click and drag to box-select.
Scroll the mouse wheel to zoom in and out.

Press C/V to change the camera's vertical rotation. Q/E changes the horizontal rotation.

If you want less restrictions with your camera, go to the options menu by selecting "escape" and enable the "free camera" setting.

Hold left-shift to speed up the camera, right-shift to slow it down. 

Toggle cinematic mode with right-shift + f (hides the UI).
Each regiment shows two bars: green for strength and blue for morale (willingness to fight).
Low morale will force a unit to retreat the battlefield.
At 0 morale, a unit becomes "shattered" and cannot be rallied.

Proper placement wins battles. Every regiment has an effective range, with damage scaling by distance. Attacking an enemy’s flanks deals even more damage.

Hold left tab to preview the movements of your regiments.
Place your regiments on favorable terrain. Hills boost accuracy, hedges/buildings provide strong cover, and forests give cover but slow movement and reduce accuracy.
Brigade officers, which are always attached to your first regiment in a brigade, grant a morale buff to any unit inside their blue command radius.

Officers also have traits that buff their brigade (1–4 regiments shown with their portrait at the bottom). </line-indent>

An officers' skills apply passively at all times, even if the units under their command are outside of the command radius.
Your general provides the strongest morale buff to nearby units, allowing regiments to fight longer.
If the general is forced to flee, the morale of your army will suffer greatly. If destroyed, the general can not die, he will become wounded and come back in a future battle.

A regiment is retreating due to low morale!</line-indent>

Retreating units will slowly replenish morale to rejoin the fight unless they reach the edge of the battlefield. 

Quickly, move your General or an officer to rally your retreating troops, unless those troops are already shattered.
Run is enabled. Don’t sprint for too long. Low stamina reduces combat effectiveness and slows movement. To recover stamina, keep the unit still and out of combat. Hotkey to enable R
Formations matter. Long lines move slowly and suffer bigger morale shocks from fire. Denser formations maneuver faster and feel safer, but trade away firepower.
Attack columns excel at charging and maneuvering. They’re easier to hit (more damage taken) but lose less morale when hit due to tight cohesion.
Marching columns are for repositioning. They’re extremely vulnerable and sacrifice most firepower for maximum mobility.
This is the halt command. The unit will stop what it’s doing. Hotkey to enable H
Toggle hold fire to disable auto-targeting. The regiment won’t fire until given a direct attack. Hotkey to enable T

Toggle volley fire (synchronized firing). Turning it off lets soldiers fire as soon as reloaded - gives more sustained damage, but less morale shock. Hotkey to enable Y
Unequipping bayonets slightly improves accuracy and reduces reload time. Keep bayonets on when charging or defending against a charge. Hotkey to enable B
Grenades selected. Left-Click to target a location. Uses are limited. Hotkey to enable G

General,

Our scouts report the enemy headquarters has mustered its full army and is marching to engage us. 

Columns move on the main road with advance guards out; expect contact within days. 

We can not outrun them, we must face them.

General, Your army stands at the frontier. Though modest in size, your forces are disciplined and in good order. A nearby depot lies ahead, lightly defended, and will serve as a starting point to begin your campaign, though you’ll need to press onward soon after. The land is open and the roads clear, ideal for seeking out skirmishes and encounters. Engage patrols boldly, even those larger than your own; their troops are of a lower quality and their spoils and equipment will serve your army well. We await your progress.

General,

Your army stands upon a new frontier. The enemy has used the lull to prepare; patrols flood the roads, and field armies will begin hunting us once we've made our presence known. 

The year has turned cold early; within weeks snow will be regular and marches will slow. Lay in provisions and firewood, and expect to fight in winter throughout this country. 

Secure your supply depot, but do not linger; press the advance before your supplies diminish.

General,

The country ahead has been put to the torch. Storehouses are empty, mills are broken, wells fouled, and what little remains is dear to buy. Morale will suffer in this barren ground; proceed with extreme caution.

The enemy has posted their best troops here to force a decisive engagement and end the war. Choose your ground carefully and press hard when you find the enemy's main body. Beat them here and the war is won. 

You have carried the army this far; hold firm and you will finish it.

General,

Winter is a month off and the first snowfall is expected. Your army will travel slower, visibility will be limited, and food consumption will increase.

Store sufficient provisions and prepare for hardship. Waiting out the season is not an option; we must secure the region before we can go into winter quarters.

General,

Although the enemy’s headquarters has fallen, their resolve has not. A fresh host has marched into the region, swift and determined to reclaim what was lost. They will begin their pursuit in a matter of weeks.

There will be no respite until this new army is broken. Rally the men, keep discipline in the ranks, and prepare for one last trial. Victory here will silence all opposition and bring the campaign to its rightful end.

Accuracy determines how much damage the regiment deals. It decreases with distance; you will lose most of your accuracy at maximum range.
Reload determines how quickly the regiment fires.
Melee determines how well the regiment performs in a long hand-to-hand engagement.
Morale determines when the regiment will break in combat. If morale reaches 10, the unit will run away. Reaching 75 and 100 morale provide combat bonuses.
Stamina determines how long a regiment can engage in combat or sprint before it suffers combat penalties from exhaustion. Reaching 75 stamina provides a combat bonus.
Reload determines how quickly the regiment fires.
Range determines how far the regiment can fire. When firing at maximum range your damage will drop off considerably.
Charge determines how well the regiment performs in an initial charge.
Move Speed determines how fast the regiment moves on the battlefield.
Regiment Size determines how many men are needed to fill the regiment.
Your currency, used to purchase items in towns, ammunition, provisions, reservists, officers and regiments.
Your food, which is consumed by your army daily.
Your manpower, which are used to replace losses in battles.
Your ammunition, which is consumed by your army in battle.
Field armies will pursue you as long as they can find you, new ones will continue to appear in the region until the headquarters is destroyed.
The headquarters army (HQ) is the primary field army in the area. Defeating it will result in the capture of the region and end the act.
Patrol armies move between settlements searching for you. They are limited in number, meaning they do not reappear when destroyed.

Encamped Armies are always stationary, and yield a Doctrine reward when defeated. They are similar to the HQ, but slightly less difficult. They are limited in number and do not reappear when destroyed.

“Sorrow is a century, death an instant.” — Frederick the Great, King in Prussia

“I seized the Frenchman by the throat… and pointed my sword at his breast.” — The Hereditary Prince of Brunswick, on forcing the crossing of the Weser

“The success of the campaign is uncertain and difficult, but I would have to overcome greater difficulties were I to give the enemy time to come at me with all his forces united.” — Prince Ferdinand of Brunswick

“[Soldiers] never abandon officers they esteem and love… We must do the same. Move to where the advanced guards are fighting and only part from them when you die alongside them!” — The Hereditary Prince of Brunswick
“Where a goat can go, a man can go, and where a man can go, he can drag a gun.” — William Phillips, British Major General
“I heard the bullets whistle, and, believe me, there is something charming in the sound.” — George Washington, British Lieutenant-Colonel
“Where some states have an army, the Prussian Army has a state.” — Voltaire, French Philosopher
“All of their science of war comes down to their bayonets and their Cossacks.” — Alexandre de Langeron, French Émigré, describing the Russian Army
“You see what a victory costs. The blood of our enemies is still the blood of men. The true glory is to spare it.” — Louis XV, King of France
“Impatience for victory guarantees defeat.” — Louis XIV, King of France
“There is little that can withstand a man who can conquer himself.” — Louis XIV, King of France
“It is not big armies that win battles, it is the good ones.” — Maurice de Saxe, French Marshal
“Every unit that is not supported is a defeated unit.” — Maurice de Saxe, French Marshal
“The men have suffered with great patience, though I will not pretend there have not been disorders.” — Louis Georges Érasme de Contades, French Marshal
“Peace would be had on better terms than with the army intact and Cassel lost, than with the army lost and Cassel intact.” — François de Broglie, French Marshal
“We should try to make war without leaving anything to chance. In this lies the talent of a general.” — Maurice de Saxe, French Marshal

“Firearms, and not cold steel, now decide battles.”
<i>— Jacques François de Chastenet de Puységur, French Marshal
“I have resolved never to start an unjust war, but never to end a legitimate one except by defeating my enemies.” — Charles XII, King of Sweden
The Seven Years’ War (1756–1763) forced Prussia and Britain to fight a grand coalition of Austria, France, Russia, Saxony, and Sweden across every continental front.
Frederick the Great's Prussian army began the Seven Years’ War with a preemptive invasion of Saxony in August 1756.
At the Battle of Soor, the Prussian Wedel Grenadier Battalion suffered 82% casualties assaulting a battery of Austrian cannon.
On European battlefields across the eighteenth century, infantrymen frequently took cover when under heavy enemy fire.
The Prussian “Death’s Head Hussars” wore black with skull insignia and became feared across Europe. Raised in the 1740s, they served as elite light cavalry.
Equipped with metal ramrods, Prussian infantry were relentlessly drilled so that they could fire faster than their opponents.
Croatian Grenzers, frontier troops from the Austrian-Turkish border, terrorized their opponents with hit-and-run ambush attacks.
In the aftermath of the Battle of Soor, Austrian light troops kidnapped Frederick the Great's dog, Biche. Frederick and Biche were reunited after the war's end.
In 1762, Empress Elizabeth died and was succeeded by Tsar Peter III, a Frederick admirer. He immediately made peace with Prussia, ending Russia’s role in the war.
European armies fielded diverse cavalry: heavy cuirassiers, nimble hussars, medium dragoons, and elite formations like Russian horse grenadiers, who combined firepower with shock tactics.
Austrian General Ernst von Laudon destroyed a full Prussian corps at Landeshut in 1760, then captured Glatz fortress in Silesia, threatening Frederick’s southern flank.
At the Battle of Hochkirch (1758), Austrian General Franz Moritz von Lacy pioneered a novel method of attacking in columns from multiple directions, which took the Prussians by surprise.
Prince Henry of Prussia, Frederick’s brother, never lost a battle during the war. His final victory at Freiberg (1762) closed the campaign in Saxony.
To counter Austrian light troops, Frederick raised Freikorps: irregular units like Kleist’s “Green Corps” of jaegers and hussars used for raiding, skirmishing, and scouting.
Cossack cavalry were irregular Russian horsemen used for scouting, raiding, and harassment. They rarely fought in set battles but made life miserable for enemy supply lines.
Though outnumbered and nearly encircled at every turn, Prussia’s survival in the Seven Years’ War earned it the status of a European great power and cemented Frederick’s legend.

In late 1761, Russian General Rumyantsev captured Kolberg, an important Prussian Baltic port. The siege enabled the Russian army to remain in Central Europe, posing a dire threat to Prussia's heartland.
As the war dragged on, Frederick placed more and more importance on artillery, especially at victories like Burkersdorf in 1762.
Hanoverian, Hessian, and Brunswicker troops fought alongside Britain and Prussia. Their infantry and cavalry played key roles at Minden, Warburg, and Wilhelmsthal.
Frederick praised Russian soldiers’ toughness. At Zorndorf and Kunersdorf, Russian battalions held firm under heavy fire, often needing to be dislodged by bayonet or cavalry.

The Prussian army used a canton system, where each regiment recruited from a specific region. Soldiers often farmed during peacetime and drilled annually before wartime mobilization, like modern reservists.
Sweden joined the war in 1757, invading Prussian Pomerania. Despite early hopes, Swedish forces failed to advance beyond Stralsund and played a minor role thereafter.
The British Army raised two Highland regiments, the 87th and 88th Foot, during the war. They served in Germany with distinction before being disbanded in 1763.
The Reichsarmee, the Army of the Holy Roman Empire, was less centralized and professional than most contemporary armies. It often struggled to face its Prussian opponents.
The Hessians and Brunswickers fought alongside the British and Hanoverians for financial as well as political reasons. Their states were paid a subsidy, helping to offset their military expenditures.
France’s initial gains in Germany collapsed after defeats at Rossbach and Minden. By 1762, French armies had been pushed back across the Rhine and lost momentum.
Grenadiers were selected for ferocity and discipline. Distinguished by tall pointed caps, they often spearheaded bayonet assaults in key battles.
Prussian fusiliers were raised from recently acquired territories such as Silesia. Although they often performed well in combat, they were sometimes suspected of having split loyalties.
British infantry were famed for their fire discipline and saw off multiple attacks by French cavalry at the Battle of Minden.
Most common soldiers were deeply religious, whether Anglican, Catholic, Calvinist, Eastern Orthodox, Lutheran, or Methodist.
Although the period is often remembered for the stately pace of its marches, soldiers would often run on the battlefield when reinforcements were needed quickly in a vital sector.
General Seydlitz revolutionized Prussian cavalry tactics. His squadrons could pivot in motion, attack in successive waves, and re-form under fire—all rare feats at the time.
The Russian Corps of Observation consisted of newly recruited soldiers enlisted at the outbreak of the war in 1756.
In January 1758, Russian forces occupied East Prussia without resistance. Königsberg surrendered, and its officials swore loyalty to Empress Elizabeth for the duration of the war.
In October 1760, a Russian corps under General Totleben captured Berlin. They held the city for three days, levied a ransom, then withdrew before Prussian reinforcements arrived.
British subsidies were vital to Prussia’s war effort. In 1758, Britain agreed to pay Frederick £670,000 per year and sent thousands of troops to Germany.
After a French victory at Hastenbeck (1757), Hanover briefly left the war. But Britain canceled the treaty after Frederick’s triumph at Rossbach, reviving the western front.
The Treaty of Hubertusburg (1763) ended the European war. No major borders changed, but Austria officially recognized Prussian control of Silesia, solidifying Prussia’s great power status.
French Guards, elite household infantry, saw little field action. Most were held in reserve or tasked with defending the French coast against a feared British landing.
Grenadiers à cheval and Royal-Allemand Cavalry served as France’s household cavalry. Despite their prestige, they had limited presence in the German theater.
Russian Shuvalov howitzers were an experimental cannon. Their distinctive muzzle shape spread canister shot more effectively.
Most armies across Europe used buckshot in addition to larger musket balls. The additional small-caliber balls wounded more enemy troops.
It was rare for frontal cavalry charges to break through formed infantry; when they attacked the flanks or rear of infantry formations, the results could be devastating.
The Prussian Grenadier-Garde, known as the Lange Kerls or Potsdam Giants, were an effective assault force during the Seven Years’ War.
One of the most famous military writers of the age was Charles-Joseph, Prince de Ligne. You can command his regiment, the de Ligne Fusiliers.
Frederick the Great promoted the cultivation of the potato despite the skepticism of his people. The potato would eventually become a staple in German cuisine.
The silver Joachimsthaler coin, first minted in Bohemia in the 1500s, became known simply as the thaler. Its name later evolved into "dollar," influencing currencies around the world.
You can tap R to toggle sprinting. Don’t sprint too long, or your men will tire and lose combat effectiveness.
The formations you draw matter. Columns move faster and charge harder, while lines provide more frontage for greater firepower.
Flanking is crucial. Attacking from the side or rear deals heavy morale damage.
You can toggle off volley fire at the bottom of the battle screen. Doing so reduces immediate morale shock but allows troops to fire more quickly.
You can remove your bayonet during battle, gaining accuracy but losing the melee and charge bonus it provides.
Units have distinct roles. Avoid sending light infantry into melee, and rely on heavy infantry for bayonet charges.
Hold Left Alt while hovering over a unit in battle to see expanded information.
Cover reduces fire damage. Forests provide cover but reduce accuracy and speed. Buildings and hedges also offer protection.
The dead don’t fight for glory. Sometimes retreat is the best way to preserve your army.
Hills provide elevation bonuses: a bit of cover, higher accuracy, and slightly faster morale recovery.
Make use of stances on the campaign map. Forced march, for example, can save you when an enemy is in pursuit.
Raiding a settlement grants money and provisions, but it costs time and angers the locals, raising prices.
Tap Escape and select Unlocks to view achievements. Progress toward these can unlock new units or army compositions.
Try equipping artillery with canister shot, it is a close-range ammunition type used for devastating direct fire.
Experiment with item combinations at camp. Specializing regiments can yield unique advantages.
Customize your regiments by selecting one at camp and clicking the flag in the lower-left corner. Officers can also be customized.
Use the unit info panel on the left side of the screen during battle. It shows items, officer effects, and other vital details.
Sieging forts can earn doctrines that aid your campaign. Be cautious, they cost men and ammunition.
Defeating encamped armies grants doctrines, though these battles are difficult.
Hover over your objectives in the top right of the campaign screen to see completion rewards.
Managing stamina is critical. Units tire from sprinting, firing, and especially from melee. Exhaustion reduces combat effectiveness.
Units above 75 stamina become invigorated, boosting combat effectiveness.
Combat Effectiveness modifies accuracy, reload, melee, and charge.
Morale has a major impact on combat effectiveness. Confident troops gain buffs, while wavering troops suffer penalties.
The red gradient in a unit’s firing arc shows its effective range. The closer the target, the higher the chance of a hit.
To set a custom movement path, hold Left Shift and right-click multiple points.
Units build up a brace when stationary, helping resist cavalry charges.
Charging from the front is far less effective than charging from the flank or rear.
Once a unit commits to a full charge, you cannot redirect it until impact.
Switching to your bayonet is faster than reloading.
Battalion artillery has fewer guns but faster reloads. They are best near the front with canister shot.
Stretching your lines increases firepower but makes them slower and more vulnerable to morale damage.
High ground boosts artillery accuracy, making shots more likely to land.
Choose charges wisely. Some units, like grenzers, are weak in melee and can be overwhelmed.
Clicking a brigade officer’s portrait selects the entire brigade.
Sometimes it’s better to hold back promotions. Higher-tier units take longer to replenish, which can slow your whole army.
Prepare for winter. Provisions are consumed faster, and starvation can destroy your army.
Retreating units can often recover with time or officer support, but shattered units never recover during battle.
Always replenish your army after battles. Replacing lost reservists and restocking ammunition is essential to keep your forces ready for the next engagement.

Chapter 1: The Shadow of Mollwitz,
(Winter, 1742 – King Friedrich’s Training Drills)

I am Friedrich, King in Prussia.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

When I inherited the throne, we were a minor power,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

respected, but never feared.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

My first battle, Mollwitz,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

should have been a triumph of discipline and theory.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Instead, I was sent from the field,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

and Generalfeldmarschall von Schwerin,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

my father’s most trusted general,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

won the day without me.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Mollwitz was a lesson:
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

the cavalry has since been reformed.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

The infantry, who stood without me,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

have been hardened into a force that will never waver.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

And this time, I will stand by my men to the end.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Your Majesty, a detachment of Austrian Grenzers,
<color=#E2A200>(Prussian Messenger)</color>

has been sighted moving over the Neisse.
<color=#E2A200>(Prussian Messenger)</color>

They appear unaware of our presence.
<color=#E2A200>(Prussian Messenger)</color>

Then they will not expect an engagement.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

We will attack.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Chapter 2: March to Redemption,
(Spring, 1742 – On the Eve of Chotusitz)

Winter in Silesia gave us confidence.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Our skirmish against the Grenzers was clean, precise.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

But now, a large Austrian force strikes at Chotusitz in Bohemia,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

and I am a day’s march away from my men.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

We must push through the night to save the army.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

This will be the true test,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

my chance to redeem Mollwitz.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

The left is collapsing.
<color=#009300>(Leopold I, Prince von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

My cavalry cannot hold.
<color=#009300>(Leopold I, Prince von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

If you delay, we lose the field.
<color=#009300>(Leopold I, Prince von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

Mollwitz was my father’s army.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Chotusitz will be mine.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Double the pace!
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

We strike before the Austrians break our line!
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Chapter 3: King’s Gambit
(Spring, 1742 – In the Aftermath of Chotusitz)

At Mollwitz, I ran.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

At Chotusitz, I marched through the night and took the field.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Silesia will be mine now,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

taken, not inherited.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

A fine victory, Your Majesty.
<color=#009300>(Kurt Christoph Graf von Schwerin)</color>

The Austrians will have no choice but to sit down at the negotiating table.
<color=#009300>(Kurt Christoph Graf von Schwerin)</color>

But peace is only borrowed time.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

The Empress will not forgive the loss of Silesia.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

And I am not finished.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>
Two Years Later – 1744, The Night Before Hohenfriedberg

The Austrians have returned.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

They think of us as passive, scattered.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

But we’ve watched their every move.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

As you ordered, your majesty
<color=#009300>(Prince Moritz von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

von Zieten’s hussars have harassed their ranks
<color=#009300>(Prince Moritz von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

and keep us informed.
<color=#009300>(Prince Moritz von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

Our spies have infiltrated their camp,
<color=#009300>(Prince Moritz von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

and are feeding the enemy misinformation.
<color=#009300>(Prince Moritz von Anhalt-Dessau)</color>

Then it’s time.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

The enemy must believe we're still waiting here.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

We march tonight.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

No talking, no smoking!
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Not a single sound.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

When the sun rises,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

we will stand in battle line,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

while the Austrians are still sipping their coffee.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Chapter 4: Fight for Survival
Autumn, 1745 – Prussian Encampment near Soor

God helped me wonderfully at Hohenfriedberg.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

But I expected Austria to seek peace,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

just as they did after Chotusitz three years ago.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

and yet their silence lingers.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Austrian forces occupy the surrounding heights…
<color=#E2A200>(Prussian Messenger)</color>

They move to encircle us!
<color=#E2A200>(Prussian Messenger)</color>

Rouse the men.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Prepare for immediate engagement.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

We must break through before their trap closes!
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Chapter 5: A Kingdom Secured
(Winter, 1745 – Sanssouci Palace, Potsdam)

Silesia is ours.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

My kingdom is safe.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

And my army has proven itself, again and again.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

again and again.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

Your Majesty,
<color=#009300>(Kurt Christoph Graf von Schwerin)</color>

The Austrians will not forgive the loss of Silesia so easily.
<color=#009300>(Kurt Christoph Graf von Schwerin)</color>

The empress will seek new allies.
<color=#009300>(Kurt Christoph Graf von Schwerin)</color>

Then we must be ready.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

This war is over.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

But the next will not be in defense of Silesia,
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

it will be for Prussia itself.
<color=#599FE0>(Friedrich II von Preußen)</color>

You've lost! If this is the headquarters battle, it unfortunately means the campaign is lost.

If this was not a headquarters battle, you can rally your forces, replenish, and fight again!
Well fought, Commander! You’ve earned spoils of war. Choose to ransom, conscript, or exchange prisoners to proceed.
An officer has been promoted! Select the upgrade button to level up your officer. You are limited to 5 traits.

This bar indicates the momentum of the unit charging. At full charge momentum, the unit utilizes 100% of its charge skill damage.
<color=#CB2225>When full charge momentum is reached the unit may not be given any additional orders until the charge is fully carried out!</color>
This bar indicates the progress of the unit's reload. At full reload the regiment will fire. If you wish to have this unit fire without delay, toggle off "volley fire" at the bottom of the screen.
Toggle hold fire to disable auto-targeting. The regiment won’t fire until given a direct attack. Hotkey to enable T

This is the morale bar. Each line segment represents around 20 morale. When a unit's morale is above <color=#009300>50</color> it will begin receiving combat effectiveness buffs. However, once morale is low and reaches <color=#CB2225>10</color> the unit becomes out of control and flees from the field. It may not be rallied if morale hits <color=#CB2225>0</color>, at which point it is shattered.
You may also select this button to add manpower or ammo to all units.
A unit requires a few days to fully recover. It depends on the unit themselves.
Your regiments will automatically target the closest enemy in range. Right click on an enemy to change targets.

Compare regiment stats and recruit cavalry, infantry, or artillery. </line-indent>

Some towns apply modifiers that raise or lower prices.

Compare officer traits and starting skills, then recruit the one that fits your strategy. </line-indent>

Some towns apply modifiers that raise or lower hiring costs.
The enemy HQ attacks on day {0}
The enemy HQ is now in pursuit!
Free camera is not recommended as the game was originally built for one perspective, but it will allow you to have more freedom to rotate the camera
You have earned enough veterancy to rank up a regiment!

The left side allows you to recolor your flag and uniform. All elements of a unit's uniform can be recolored. Select part of the uniform on the bust, then select one of the "Current Uniform Colors." You can then recolor that part of the uniform by selecting any color underneath the "Color Palette."

Your army is marching on empty! If you are out of <sprite name=food> provisions, it will deplete your <sprite name=manpower> reservists.

When you are out of provisions and reservists, your regiments will leave your army and the campaign will be lost.
An enemy patrol has been sighted! Engage whenever possible, their ranks are poor quality. Defeating them yields modest but vital resources.
An enemy field army has been sighted! These armies are tough but yield better rewards than a patrol. Field armies appear in the region at random times and come after you.

An enemy encamped army has been sighted! These are difficult enemies but yield rewards equal to the enemy headquarters. You will receive a new doctrine if you can manage to beat one! Losing a battle against an encamped army does not end the campaign.
Enemy headquarters spotted! Defeating this army will bring the campaign in this region to a close. If your army loses to the headquarters, the campaign is completely lost.
After selecting your nation and any difficulty modifiers, press CONTINUE to begin your first campaign.
Scroll the mouse wheel to zoom in and out.

Press C/V to change the camera's vertical rotation. Q/E changes the horizontal rotation.

If you want less restrictions with your camera, go to the options menu by selecting "escape" and enable the "free camera" setting.

Hold left-shift to speed up the camera, right-shift to slow it down. 

Toggle cinematic mode with right-shift + f (hides the UI).
Use these buttons to change the battle speed. Press space to pause quickly.

Welcome to the Master of Command demo! You will encounter some bugs and balance issues. Join our Discord server if you have any questions!

Here are the biggest known issues:
• Localization is not yet finished: we recommend playing the game in English, the translations are placeholder.
• Resolution issues: we are still adding support for more resolutions, so please be patient as we roll out improvements.
• Tutorial text: the tutorial is still a work in progress. You may notice some awkward wording or missing explanations.
After moving your regiments, you can preview their position by holding left tab.
Are you sure you want to reset your uniform?
Do you want to keep your customized uniform colors?
The shop does not have the funds to cover the transaction, do you want to continue?
Are you sure you want to quit?
Use Non Historical Enemies By Default
You can drag and drop your mods to choose what order they are loaded in, alternatively you can right click on them to switch which group they are in.
Your game must be restarted to load your mod changes
This mod is locally installed on your pc rather than steam workshop
